text:
<!here|@here>: I have a component that implements `mouseEnter` to conditionally show a link in the template. in my acceptance test I am trying to trigger the mouse enter event so I can see the link. To do this I'm using:

```
andThen(function() {
  triggerEvent('.fo-bar', 'mouseenter');
});
```

However, the link is not showing....Am I missing something here?
wasn’t `mouseenter` a “special” event in some way? Like, it was an abstraction added by jQuery or something like that...
dunno...That's what I was hoping you'd be able to tell me :simple_smile:
hmm… I’m trying to recall my experiences mocking events with webdriver… Oh, those were the times… not
I have solved it by using `find('.foo-bar').trigger('mouseover');` instead
"The mouseenter JavaScript event is proprietary to Internet Explorer. Because of the event's general utility, jQuery simulates this event so that it can be used regardless of browser."

attachments.title: .mouseenter() | jQuery API Documentation
attachments.text: jQuery: The Write Less, Do More, JavaScript Library

text: Maybe try with `mouseover` and see if jQuery converts it to `mouseenter`?
I used `mouseenter` as that seems to be what has been used in quite a few other places in the code base...not sure what the difference is.
the difference is that `mouseover` fires constantly while you are over an element. `mouseenter` only fires on entry
did that work or did you do something else?

attachments.fallback: [May 11th, 2016 9:31 AM] aaron: I have solved it by using `find('.foo-bar').trigger('mouseover');` instead
attachments.text: I have solved it by using `find('.foo-bar').trigger('mouseover');` instead

text: <@U03V8V08M> Thanks, that package looks super useful generally. Think I’m getting somewhere with this problem slowly

Update: I have found `ds-references` :heart: So can now check in my view if a user id is in the related set of owner ids quite cleanly: `model.hasMany('owners').ids()`. Would love if JSON API and Ember support pivot table attributes one day though.
<http://emberjs.com/blog/2016/01/12/ember-data-2-3-released.html#toc_code-ds-references-code>

attachments.text: Ember.js helps developers be more productive out of the box. Designed with developer ergonomics in mind, its friendly APIs help you get your job done—fast.
